monogr.title: A most excellent and learned vvoorke of chirurgerie, called Chirurgia parua Lanfranci : Lanfranke of Mylayne his briefe: reduced from dyuers translations to our vulgar or vsuall frase, and now first published in the Englyshe prynte by Iohn Halle chirurgien. Who hath thervnto necessarily annexed. A table, as wel of the names of diseases and simples with their vertues, as also of all other termes of the arte opened. ... And in the ende a compendious worke of anatomie ... An historiall expostulation also against the beastly abusers, both of chyrurgerie and phisicke in our tyme: with a goodly doctrine, and instruction, necessary to be marked and folowed of all true chirurgie [n] s. All these faithfully gathered, and diligently set forth, by the sayde Iohn Halle
monogr.author: Lanfranco, of Milan

div.p: SEing that (dere brethrē) to publish these gestes, to the prospect and iudgment of the rude multitude (from whose face then it can not be kepte,) is an enterprise no lesse dangerous, then to commit a skiffe or small whirey charged, to horryble tempestes on the raginge seas: howe greate cause hath my brother had, to detracte or delaye the time of publishing the same? yea how lyttle maruel had it bene, if when it was finyshed, he had neuer doen it? So it might otherwise haue ioinde to oure handes: for whose sakes he bothe tooke the paynes, and is content to beare the bitter woundes of scornfull sclaunders dartes, shotte alwaies by the arme of ignorance. Not doubtinge thy good nature to be euer prest, to thinke and saye the best, and to take all thynges tollerable in good parte, wherby thou mayste render to hym his hartes desire: whyche is also no more then duetye, for of mere good wyll I ensure thee he hathe done it. Thoughe perhaps it maye more please some man to iudge wt lesse loue, yt vaine glory was hereof the efficient cause. to whome I saye, that vayne in dede are all men and theyr thoughtes: nether is there anye thinge as the Apostle saythe, wherin we shoulde reioyce, or whereof we shoulde boaste, but onlye the crosse of Christe: yt is, hys paciēt death & giltlesse sufferāce, for vs wretches. In respect wherof all other things are very vain. And Gloria sayth Seneca, vanū & volatile quiddâ est, aura • mobilius. That is glory is a vain and fletyng thing, and more wauering then the winde. Whiche vaine glorye in deede (as he also noteth in an other Epistle, couplinge it wyth ambition,) hathe doubtlesse caused diuers hyghe potentates to attempt manye dangerous, yea and sometime most wicked enterpryces. And is no doubte at this daye one vice cleauinge almoste in euery mannes bosome: so large is follyes reigne.

But as lyke Parasites wyth friuolous adulatyons, to rocke suche fooles a sleape (to whome it weare muche more meete wyth bytter tauntes to bridle theyr endlesse arrogancye,) it is not a womanlye follye, but a very wickednesse, yea more then bestiall: so to withholde good reporte, (whyche is Vera virtutis gloria,) from any that hath of mere good wyll (by anye vertuous trauell) profited the common weale, or (which is worse) in stead therof to calumniate, is a heathenish iniury: (but I might more rightly say an iniury, which ought amōg ye godlesse heathen rather to be sought, but alasse whyche is now among vs chrystians much more frequent.) For who planteth a vyneyarde, & tasteth not of the frute? who fedeth a flock, and cateth not of the milke?

Of thys glory (as contrary to the former as light vnto darknesse) Seneca speakinge in Epistola. 80. ad Lucilium saythe, Gloria vmbra
virtutis est, etiam inuitos comitabitur. Sed quemadmodum aliquan do vmbra antecedit, aliquando sequitur, vel a tergo est: Ita gloria aliquando ante nos est, visendamque se praebet, aliquando in averso est, maiorque quo serior, vbi inuidia secessit. That is: glorye is the shadowe of vertue, and wyll accompany euen suche as are not desirous of hir, or couet hir not. But as the shadowe goeth sometimes before, and sometime foloweth, or is behinde: euen so is glory somtime before vs, and offereth hyr selfe to be sene and somtimes after or behynde vs. And the later, the greater it is, when enuye hathe geuen plac • .

Hereof also Cicero in Laelio sayth, Praestantes viri nunquam tanta conati essent, quae ad posteritatis memoriam pertinerent, ni animo vidissent posteritatem ad se pertinere posse. Nonne melius multo fuisset, otio sam aetatem & quietam sine vllo labore & contentione traducere? Worthye men saythe he, woulde neuer attempt so great thinges, that mighte continue vnto posteritye, vnlesse they did foresee that the posteritye mighte belonge vnto them: For weare it not elsse muche better to leade an idle and quyet life, wythoute any labor or contention?

And who so wyll from time to time, marke the conditions of all ages: shall skant fynde one, that for hys labors taken, and perilles susteined,Cicero proarch poeta. desireth not glory as a reward for his dedes. For the Philosophers them selues, euen in the bookes that they wrote in the contempt of glory, haue wrytten theyr owne names: so that wherin they despise fame, and nobility, yet would they haue them selues named, & made famoue.

And agayne he saythe. Nullam virtus aliam mercedem laborum, periculorumque desiderat, praeter laudis & gloriae: Qua quidem de tracta, quid est 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in hoc tam exiguo vitae curriculo, & tam breui, tantis nos in laboribus exerceamus? To saye, vertue desyreth none other recompence of hyr labors and perils, but prayse and glory: whych beinge taken awaye, what is there, for the whych we should in so small and short a course of life, vexe our selues with so great laboures. A like sayinge he hathe in his Philippicis.

Nullam mercedem tanta virtus, praeter hanc laudis et gloria de siderat: qua etiam si careat, tamen est seipsa contenta. Quanquam in memoria gratorū hoīm, tanquam in luce posita letetur. which is, Uertue only desyreth none other reward, but laud & glory: which truelye if she lacke, yet is she contented: althoughe she reioyce in the memory of thankfull men, as placed in the lighte. Loe heare see you that true glory or honest fame, is the good reporte of iuste men, for vertuous trauels, and honest desertes: a dette whyche the benefyte receiuers oughte moste willyngly to pay, thoughe not of the deseruers to be ouer busilye craued, seing that as of the wycked, (whose loue is enuy, and his praise sclaunder,) it can not be had: so of the vertuous, who is neuer vnthākfull, it can not be wythholden.

And whether I may in my brother hys behalf, require this at your handes, as a well deserued duetye, let the thynge it self wyth his frutes
be iudge (least I should say more then me besemeth.) Is firste in trāslating, and reducing to perfection, Lanfrancus his lyttle worke of chirurgery, (not the worste wryter of that age, as hys so muche profytable doctrine, in suche breuity, dothe ryght will declare.) Then for hys exposityue table therof, whiche he hathe gathered and adioyned therto. And lastly for his Anatomy in the end: bothe the whyche, he hathe (at my sute partly) decked with the Greeke, as wel as the Latin names, of symples, diseases, members. &c. as the purpose of teachinge the yoūger sorte gaue occasion: that suche as are as well as I, desirous of knowledge in bothe the tongues, myght layntlye receiue some vtilitye, (or at least delight) therby: Trustinge that others will fauorablye permit the same, as a thing to them though not delightful, yet no impediment.

In readynge all the which, I trust you wil not repent your paines, for truely these for the most part are not his, but (as ye may easily see,) the authorityes of the moste worthy, and best approued wryters, wherin if you shall finde any thinge, (whether it be his owne, or amonge the authorities,) to be misliked: Examine it fyrste wyth reason, vpryghte iudgment, and like authorities. By all the whiche if it be found faulty: Consider, that hominis est errare, (neither hathe anye man as I suppose in humane sciences, otherwise wrytten,) and that muche better it is to erre, wyth the learned and vnder correction, then singularly of self wyll or stubberne opinyon.

But opinyon is nowe a dayes so beloued, that men had muche rather wt toothe & nayle defend the same (yea though truth be therby vtterly defaced,) thē to geue ouer to reasō or good authority. which thing ryghte well noteth Seneca sayinge. Inter cetera mortalltatis incommoda, & haec est caligo mētiū, nec tantū necessitas errandi, sed erro • ū amor. That is among other discommedities of mortall men, thys is the darknesse of myndes: not onlye the necessitye of errynge, but also the loue of the same.

Whome therfore shall I iudge more happye and wyse, then hym that is free from error, or at least no slaue to opinion: Then the which there is not a greater enemy to truthe and perfect knowledge. Bothe the whyche louynge brethren, I beseche the eternall God to plante in vs, to hys endlesse glorye, and the profyte of hys creatures, and to the vtter banishment of that ougly monster Ignorance.
